natural problem: Alex has four books of different sizes which he wishes to place on a bookshelf. Unfortunately, the bookshelf has a conspicuous hole at one end through which only the smallest book can fall. If he wishes for all his books to stay stationary, in how many ways can he arrange his books?
natural solution: The smallest book cannot be placed at one end, so there are three positions which it can occupy. The other books can each be placed in any of the three remaining positions, giving $3!$ arrangements.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_ways = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..4}. i) - 1"
shows  "num_ways = 18"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex has four books of different sizes which he wishes to place on a bookshelf. Unfortunately, the bookshelf has a conspicuous hole at one end through which only the smallest book can fall. If he wishes for all his books to stay stationary, in how many ways can he arrange his books? The final Answer is 18\text{ ways. }
 ### Proof
 The smallest book cannot be placed at one end, so there are three positions which it can occupy. The other books can each be placed in any of the three remaining positions, giving $3!$ arrangements.
 Therefore, the answer is $3\times3!=\boxed{18\text{ ways. }}$
 *)

theorem
fixes num_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_ways = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..4}. i) - 1"
shows  "num_ways = 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many ways are there if we add up the numbers from 1 to 4 and then subtract 1? The final answer is 18.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes book_permutations :: nat
assumes h0 : "book_permutations = fact 4 - fact 3"
shows  "book_permutations = 18"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex has four books of different sizes which he wishes to place on a bookshelf. Unfortunately, the bookshelf has a conspicuous hole at one end through which only the smallest book can fall. If he wishes for all his books to stay stationary, in how many ways can he arrange his books? The final Answer is 18\text{ ways. }
 ### Proof
 The smallest book cannot be placed at one end, so there are three positions which it can occupy. The other books can each be placed in any of the three remaining positions, giving $3!$ arrangements.
 Therefore, the answer is $3\times3!=\boxed{18\text{ ways. }}$
 *)

theorem
fixes book_permutations :: nat
assumes h0 : "book_permutations = fact 4 - fact 3"
shows  "book_permutations = 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: How many ways can 4 books be arranged on a shelf if one book is removed before arranging? The final answer is 18.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes books :: nat and arrangement :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "books = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>i j. i \<noteq> j \<and> 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> books \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> books \<longrightarrow> arrangement i \<noteq> arrangement j"
and h2 : "arrangement 1 = 1"
shows  "card {arrangement. \<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> books \<and> arrangement i \<noteq> arrangement (i + 1)} = 18"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex has four books of different sizes which he wishes to place on a bookshelf. Unfortunately, the bookshelf has a conspicuous hole at one end through which only the smallest book can fall. If he wishes for all his books to stay stationary, in how many ways can he arrange his books? The final Answer is 18\text{ ways. }
 ### Proof
 The smallest book cannot be placed at one end, so there are three positions which it can occupy. The other books can each be placed in any of the three remaining positions, giving $3!$ arrangements.
 Therefore, the answer is $3\times3!=\boxed{18\text{ ways. }}$
 *)

theorem
fixes books :: nat and arrangement :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "books = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>i j. i \<noteq> j \<and> 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> books \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> books \<longrightarrow> arrangement i \<noteq> arrangement j"
and h2 : "arrangement 1 = 1"
shows  "card {arrangement. \<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> books \<and> arrangement i \<noteq> arrangement (i + 1)} = 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: There are 4 books on a shelf, and each book has a distinct position. If the first book's position is 1, how many different arrangements of the books are there such that no two consecutive books have consecutive positions? The final answer is 18.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes books :: nat
assumes h0 : "books = 4"
and h1 : "book_positions = permute books"
shows  "book_arrangement_ways = 18"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex has four books of different sizes which he wishes to place on a bookshelf. Unfortunately, the bookshelf has a conspicuous hole at one end through which only the smallest book can fall. If he wishes for all his books to stay stationary, in how many ways can he arrange his books? The final Answer is 18\text{ ways. }
 ### Proof
 The smallest book cannot be placed at one end, so there are three positions which it can occupy. The other books can each be placed in any of the three remaining positions, giving $3!$ arrangements.
 Therefore, the answer is $3\times3!=\boxed{18\text{ ways. }}$
 *)

theorem
fixes books :: nat
assumes h0 : "books = 4"
and h1 : "book_positions = permute books"
shows  "book_arrangement_ways = 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given that there are 4 books, find the number of ways to arrange them. The final answer is 18.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes books :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "books 1 < books 2 \<and> books 2 < books 3 \<and> books 3 < books 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>a b c d. a < b \<and> b < c \<and> c < d \<longrightarrow> books a < books b \<and> books b < books c \<and> books c < books d"
and h2 : "arrangements = card { (a, b, c, d) | a b c d. a < b \<and> b < c \<and> c < d \<and> books a < books b \<and> books b < books c \<and> books c < books d}"
shows  "arrangements = 18"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex has four books of different sizes which he wishes to place on a bookshelf. Unfortunately, the bookshelf has a conspicuous hole at one end through which only the smallest book can fall. If he wishes for all his books to stay stationary, in how many ways can he arrange his books? The final Answer is 18\text{ ways. }
 ### Proof
 The smallest book cannot be placed at one end, so there are three positions which it can occupy. The other books can each be placed in any of the three remaining positions, giving $3!$ arrangements.
 Therefore, the answer is $3\times3!=\boxed{18\text{ ways. }}$
 *)

theorem
fixes books :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "books 1 < books 2 \<and> books 2 < books 3 \<and> books 3 < books 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>a b c d. a < b \<and> b < c \<and> c < d \<longrightarrow> books a < books b \<and> books b < books c \<and> books c < books d"
and h2 : "arrangements = card { (a, b, c, d) | a b c d. a < b \<and> b < c \<and> c < d \<and> books a < books b \<and> books b < books c \<and> books c < books d}"
shows  "arrangements = 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: There are 4 books with distinct heights, and the heights follow the pattern: the height of the first book is less than the second book, the height of the second book is less than the third book, and the height of the third book is less than the fourth book. How many ways can you arrange these 4 books such that the height of each book is less than the height of the book to its right? The final answer is 18 ways.

fixes num_of_ways :: int

a_6.informal problem: Find the difference between the factorial of 4 and the factorial of 3. The final answer is 18.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes books :: "nat set"
and arrangements :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "card books = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>book. book \<in> books \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>size. size_of book = size)"
and h2 : "arrangements = card {p. p permutes books \<and> (\<forall>i<3. size_of (p i) > size_of (p (Suc i)))}"
shows  "arrangements = 18"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex has four books of different sizes which he wishes to place on a bookshelf. Unfortunately, the bookshelf has a conspicuous hole at one end through which only the smallest book can fall. If he wishes for all his books to stay stationary, in how many ways can he arrange his books? The final Answer is 18\text{ ways. }
 ### Proof
 The smallest book cannot be placed at one end, so there are three positions which it can occupy. The other books can each be placed in any of the three remaining positions, giving $3!$ arrangements.
 Therefore, the answer is $3\times3!=\boxed{18\text{ ways. }}$
 *)

theorem
fixes books :: "nat set"
and arrangements :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "card books = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>book. book \<in> books \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>size. size_of book = size)"
and h2 : "arrangements = card {p. p permutes books \<and> (\<forall>i<3. size_of (p i) > size_of (p (Suc i)))}"
shows  "arrangements = 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: There are 4 books with different sizes. How many ways can you arrange these books in a row such that the size of each book is greater than the size of the book to its right? The final answer is 18.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 4"
shows  "card (permutations_with_condition n (\<lambda>p. p 1 \<noteq> 1)) = 18"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex has four books of different sizes which he wishes to place on a bookshelf. Unfortunately, the bookshelf has a conspicuous hole at one end through which only the smallest book can fall. If he wishes for all his books to stay stationary, in how many ways can he arrange his books? The final Answer is 18\text{ ways. }
 ### Proof
 The smallest book cannot be placed at one end, so there are three positions which it can occupy. The other books can each be placed in any of the three remaining positions, giving $3!$ arrangements.
 Therefore, the answer is $3\times3!=\boxed{18\text{ ways. }}$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 4"
shows  "card (permutations_with_condition n (\<lambda>p. p 1 \<noteq> 1)) = 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: How many permutations of the numbers 1 to 4 are there such that the first element is not equal to 1? The final answer is 18.
